ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Each class was a student led discussion on papers we read before class. No new materials were learned and the instructors did not lecture. Hard to learn new things when you read the papers before class then just talked about them all class period every week.

This course was extremely valuable in gaining a holistic understanding of a system. It took a little while to get into a good flow, probably because the students had such diverse interests. However, it was a rare and very practical opportunity to learn each other's areas of interest because it led to a more complete understanding of the environment we were looking at; one where the physical, biosphysical, and social are inextricably linked like any other. The fieldwork and background readings were very useful.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip was amazing. redeeming part of the class.

Learning from classmates who bring differing expertise to the discussion. Also, the trip down to Roatan complemented our in-classroom time and deepened understanding about the complexities of island coastal development.
Contextualizing material through field trip and continuing to work with topics post-trip ; group connections it facilitated
The trip was very insightful and the readings were interesting. I particularly enjoyed the discussions.

The course was a very thorough exploration of small island land development and the impacts of this. The field trip ensured that we had a very thorough appreciation for and understanding of the impacts of development on the Roatan community. I learnt a significant amount during this course, but not exactly what I had expected to learn.
The field trip!
Very responsive professors, a tight network of peers that developed among the class with the potential to collaborate in the future, and an eye-opening and well-rounded, respectful field trip
The field trip is rather enlightening. The instructors each have their own interests and specialities, but are open to student who have different interests from theirs.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Dont just do lit reviews every week. we are there to learn not just talk about 2 papers we read before class.

Class discussion focused very closely on specific papers we read each week. Some of those papers were fascinating and provided very useful information, while others were less engaging or seemed less fundamental, especially when presented by fellow classmates. Perhaps a few minutes of lecture by the instructors to put the class topic in context would benefit some weeks' discussions. Overall, though, the readings built off each other well.
Group meetings night before on trip detailing plan for next day; perhaps heighten mix of material covered by professors and material covered by students

The class felt almost entirely like a student run discussion, it would be nice to have had more instruction from Gabe and Mary Beth, since their lectures were fantastic and insightful. Maybe it would be better to have them lead more of the discussions or lecture more often.

I would have preferred a little more lecturing from instructors and a little less student led discussion. The student discussions were very interesting and very helpful but weighted a little heavily towards student presentations instead of instructor presentations.

Information from several visits during the field trip was repetitive. A lot of the materials RMP and BICA presented had already been covered in class. Instead, there could have been more open discussion and Q&A, just like the night when the Polo Water engineer (sorry I forgot his name) came. In the future the field trip could have featured more stakeholders, such as local school teachers/students, fishers, and local residents of other industries (e.g. construction workers).

Because this was the first year that the class took place on Roatan, there are a lot of directions it can go. If we can figure out a way to build on past research, and to work with local people from different fields (both scientific and social science) to make the student projects relevant and useful to local people, it would be fantastic.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Good ties between material covered and field work over trip

In-class reading discussions could be better facilitated and structured. Oftentimes the discussion would be dominated by a handful of people who are more interested or had more experience in the topic. Very often would the discussion digress from the core information of the readings into superficial or peripheral topics and irrelevant anecdotal accounts. In the future this could be improved by asking the presenter to first give a short, 15-20 min summary of the papers, and then go around the room inviting each student ask one question about the papers for others to answer/discuss, before going to open and general discussions on the topic of the day.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided one of the few opportunities to focus on coastal and marine issues at F&ES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This course provided one of the few opportunities to focus on coastal and marine issues at F&ES, and this year's focus on marine protected areas was particularly interesting to me.
Dig deeper into coastal issues in an academic & case study context
It was particularly relevant to my coursework and area of interest!
One of the few (maybe only?) course that would allow me to explore my interests in the intersection of tourism and conservation

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes - I learned a lot about the many drivers and impacts of coastal development
Yes
Yes, the course was overall great.
Yes, it was one of the most useful and eye-opening courses I've taken at FES
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Potential exists for more group work in final project scenarios

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Get going on your project early!

This course is very dependant on vigourous student discussion and engagement. You will likely learn a lot about marine management, tourism related development and the challenges of uncontrolled growth on small islands. Overall I really enjoyed this class a lot.
Select a term project that is feasible within the scope of this course.
Talk to Gabe and Mary Beth to gauge the relevance of your research interest to course material. This is not a course to take just for the trip.
